Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a tenant is entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment and the landlord’s failure to take reasonable steps to abate substantial and ongoing intrusions upon the tenant’s possession and use of the premises — including significant pest infestations that render premises unfit for ordinary residential use — constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a tenant is entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment and the landlord’s failure to take reasonable steps to abate substantial and ongoing intrusions upon the tenant’s possession and use of the premises — including significant pest infestations that render premises unfit for ordinary residential use — constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The case is a California Supreme Court decision establishing an implied warranty of habitability and discussing constructive eviction/quiet enjoyment principles largely under California law and general common law, not Massachusetts law. While it cites and briefly describes Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway (a Massachusetts case) and notes that court’s recognition of an implied warranty of habitability, this opinion itself does not articulate Massachusetts’ covenant of quiet enjoyment standards or specifically address a landlord’s duty under Massachusetts law regarding pest infestations. Thus it cannot be relied on as direct authority for the detailed Massachusetts-law proposition stated.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: “The Supreme Court of Wisconsin was the first to adopt this approach in 1961, and since 1969 the Supreme Courts of Hawaii, New Jersey, New Hampshire, Illinois, Iowa, and Massachusetts and the Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia have followed this lead. [fn. 12] … Moreover, lower courts in several additional states have also recently recognized the existence of an implied warranty of habitability.” (10 Cal.3d at 628.)

Hilder v. St. Peter\u2019s Roman Catholi.raw_text: Hilder v. St. Peter’s Roman Catholic Church, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I. 1984)
Hilder v. St. Peter\u2019s Roman Catholi.proposition: Massachusetts courts and other authorities recognize that substantial interferences — including persistent infestations that a landlord negligently or intentionally fails to abate — can constitute breaches of landlord obligations and justify tenant damages and injunctive relief.
Hilder v. St. Peter\u2019s Roman Catholi.support_reasoning: The case adopts an implied warranty of habitability and holds that substantial defects affecting health and safety (including conditions like sewage, leaks, inoperable toilet, and threats to safety) constitute a breach of the landlord’s obligations and justify tenant damages, including reimbursement of rent and additional compensatory damages, and potentially punitive damages. While the opinion does not specifically discuss insect or rodent infestations or injunctive relief, it expressly recognizes that conditions such as infestations and similar substantial interferences fall within the scope of habitability breaches warranting damages. Thus it generally supports the broader proposition that substantial interferences, negligently or intentionally not abated, can justify tenant remedies.
Hilder v. St. Peter\u2019s Roman Catholi.relevant_excerpt:
Damages for annoyance and discomfort are reasonable in light of the fact that

  "the residential tenant who has suffered a breach of the warranty . . . cannot bathe as frequently as he would like or at all if there is inadequate hot water; he must worry about rodents harassing his children or spreading disease if the premises are infested; or he must avoid certain rooms or worry about catching a cold if there is inadequate weather protection or heat. Thus, discomfort and annoyance are the common injuries caused by each breach . . . ."

105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Massachusetts S.raw_text: 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Massachusetts State Sanitary Code: Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation)
105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Massachusetts S.proposition: The State Sanitary Code and local housing and public health standards establish minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, and persistent rodent infestation is recognized as a condition inconsistent with the habitability and quiet enjoyment of rented premises.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111 (public health a.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111 (public health and sanitation statutes authorizing enforcement of sanitary standards).
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111 (public health a.proposition: The State Sanitary Code and local housing and public health standards establish minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, and persistent rodent infestation is recognized as a condition inconsistent with the habitability and quiet enjoyment of rented premises.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (general landlor.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (general landlord-tenant law)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (general landlor.proposition: Under general Massachusetts landlord-tenant law and related principles, a landlord is obligated to remedy conditions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s possession and use of the premises.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (summary process.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (summary process provisions governing possessory disputes and rents)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (summary process.proposition: Under general Massachusetts landlord-tenant law and related principles, a landlord is obligated to remedy conditions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s possession and use of the premises.
